original: Holmqvist, Otto Georg, major, godsägare, Sotared, Borgstena, f. 22/4/90 i Grovared, Älvsb. 1, av godsäg. Carl Fredrik H. o. Matilda Andersson. G. 18 m. Elsa Bengtsson. Barn: Ella f. 19, Bengt 22, Inga 32. — Stud:ex. 12, off:ex. 14, AIHS 17, GCI 20. Und:-löjtn. v. Göta art:reg. 14, löjtn. 17, på överg:stat 28, kapt. i reg. 29, major i armén o. avsk. 40. Tekn. chef f. Götaälvdalens Omnibus A-B 24-36, äg. o. bruk. Sotareds egend. i Älvsb. 1. Ordf. i Gbgs distr, idr:förb. 24-46, därefter hed:ordf., led. av Riksidr :förb. överstyr, sed. 28, v. ordf. i styr. f. Gbgs sttadls idr:pl!atser 40-44, ordf. i orgikomm. f. V. internat. dövstum-spelen i Sth!l!m 3(9 m. m. Sv. miäst. i liängdhopp 11, inneh. sv. rek. i höjdhopp. Medarb. i ti din. i motor- o. hästsport. RSO, RNO, RVO, Gbgs diistr. idir:förb. förtj :GM, Idr: ringens i Gbgs förtj :GM, Sv. idr:förb. förtj :-SM, FMM, Riksidr :förb. föritj :t i guM, KAK för arm. i guild.
translated: Holmqvist, Otto Georg was a major, landowner, Sotared, Borgstena, born on April 22, 1890 in Grovared, Älvsborg County. He was the son of landowner Carl Fredrik H. and Matilda Andersson. He married Elsa Bengtsson in 1918, and they had three children: Ella (born in 1919), Bengt (born in 1922), and Inga (born in 1932). Otto Holmqvist completed his secondary school studies in 1912, officer training in 1914, then studied at the Artillery and Engineering College (AIHS) from 1914 to 1917 before studying at the General Staff College (GCI) in 1920. He served as second lieutenant in the Göta Artillery Regiment in 1914, lieutenant in 1917, and was transferred to the Reserve in 1928; he became captain in 1929 and retired as major in the army in 1940. From 1924 to 1936, he was a technical manager for Götaälvdalens Omnibus A-B, and he owned and managed Sotared's estate in Älvsborg County. From 1924 to 1946 he was chairman of the Gothenburg district sports association and later became honorary chairman. He was a member of the governing board of the Swedish Sports Confederation from 1928, and vice-chairman of the board for the Gothenburg City sports venues from 1940 to 1944. In 1939, he was chairman of the organizing committee for the West International Deaf Dumb Games in Stockholm and medaled in Swedish long jump in 1911 (also holding the Swedish record in high jump). Additionally, he contributed to publications about motor and equestrian sports. He was honored with the Order of the Sword, the Order of Vasa, and the Order of the Polar Star. Holmqvist also received the Gothenburg district sports association's merit gold medal, the Gothenburg boxing ring's merit gold medal, and the Swedish Sports Confederation's merit silver medal. He received the Royal Swedish Gymnastics Central Institute's medal for military instructions.
